concern:
Iâ€™ve officially just joined my lab and Iâ€™ve been having a rough first couple months trying to get a complicated  cloning project to work. Iâ€™m inexperienced in molecular cloning, but Iâ€™m now on my twelfth (!) attempt and Iâ€™m feeling very down and itâ€™s hard not to take it to heart. 

Iâ€™ve made various mistakes along the way. Once, on attempt 9 I did something truly stupid (wrong antibiotic lol) but I caught and fixed it quickly and it just took a few extra hours. Once we ran out of a key reagent because someone left an empty tube in a box and never ordered more (it was difficult to see it was empty before I thawed it) so I had to start over. Another time the undergrad intern used all 30 vials of the bacteria I needed the morning I needed them, without informing anyone. So my fault for only checking the freezer the morning of the experiment and not immediately before starting, but also in my opinion this is a broader lab organization issue. The other times were issues by relying on protocols that were not well-optimized for my project (par for the course I guess). The latest is that I now need to re-design most of my strategy as I was following the instructions of someone who did a cloning project with the same backbone only to find that their instructions were incorrect and ignored a key gene in the vector. This is something I feel awful for not catching sooner in hindsight but again, I am inexperienced so it did not jump out to me until my PI finally noticed it today. 

Iâ€™m not repeating the same mistakes but the sheer number of mistakes on the same step of a project is making me feel like Iâ€™m the problem. Itâ€™s driving me crazy and I keep going back and forth on how much of it is my fault or just unfortunate.

TLDR: How do you guys handle the kind of mistakes where you donâ€™t know what you can do better except gain knowledge and experience over time? How do you not cry in the shower everyday? Send help ðŸ˜‚

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm excited to listen to what's on your mind and work together to find solutions that feel right for you. Please feel free to share whatever you're comfortable with, and I'll be here to support you every step of the way. ðŸŒ±

Thanks, Iâ€™m glad to be here and have someone to talk through this with. Iâ€™ve just been really struggling with a project at my lab, and itâ€™s got me feeling pretty down about myself and my abilities.

That sounds really tough, and I can imagine how frustrating and discouraging it must feel to be stuck in this situation. Can you tell me more about what's been challenging with the project and how it's been affecting you?

Yeah, itâ€™s just been a constant cycle of setbacks with this project, and itâ€™s really hitting my confidence hard. I keep wondering if Iâ€™m just not cut out for this kind of work, even though I know deep down Iâ€™m still learning.

I guess Iâ€™m just trying to figure out how to not let every little mistake feel like a personal failure, you know? Like, I want to keep pushing forward, but itâ€™s exhausting feeling like Iâ€™m always messing up. How do people deal with that kind of frustration without losing it?

It's really brave of you to share that, and I can hear how much this situation has been weighing on you. You mentioned wanting to keep pushing forward, but it's exhausting to feel like you're always messing upâ€”can you tell me more about what keeps you going despite the frustration?

Thanks for saying that, it helps to hear Iâ€™m not totally off base for feeling this way. I guess what keeps me going is just not wanting to let my PI or myself down, and knowing that if I can just get past this hurdle, itâ€™ll be a huge step forward in my skills and my project.

That's a really powerful motivation, and it shows how much you care about your work and your growth. It sounds like there's a part of you that still believes in your ability to push through and come out stronger on the other sideâ€”even if it doesn't always feel that way in the moment. Can you tell me more about what that belief looks like when you're feeling less overwhelmed?

Yeah, I appreciate that perspective. When Iâ€™m not totally buried under the frustration, that belief kinda feels like a quiet reminder that Iâ€™ve made it this far, you know, through undergrad and getting into grad school, so I must have something going for me even if I canâ€™t see it right now.

That quiet reminder sounds like a powerful ally, especially when you're feeling overwhelmed. It's interesting how your belief in yourself is rooted in your past successes, even if they're not always at the forefront of your mind. Can you think of any ways to nurture that belief when you're in the thick of frustration, so it can be a louder voice guiding you forward?

Thanks, thatâ€™s a good way to frame it. I guess maybe I could try jotting down a quick note or something about a past win, like getting into this program or even a small lab success, and keep it somewhere visible to remind myself Iâ€™ve got this, even on the rough days.
That sounds like a thoughtful strategy to keep your quiet reminder front and center. Have you ever tried something similar before, or is this a new approach for you?

Thanks for the encouragement. I havenâ€™t really done something like this before, so itâ€™s kinda new territory, but Iâ€™m willing to give it a shot since I need all the positive vibes I can get right now.

Itâ€™s great to see you embracing this new approach, and I can sense your willingness to explore different strategies. How do you envision incorporating this note-keeping practice into your daily routine, and what kind of support or reminders might help you stay consistent?

Thanks for sticking with me on this. Iâ€™m thinking I could maybe keep a little sticky note on my lab bench or in my notebook, just somewhere Iâ€™ll see it every day, and I might set a quick phone reminder to jot down a positive thought if Iâ€™m feeling super stressed. How do you think that sounds, like, would that be enough to keep me on track, or should I brainstorm some other backup ideas too?

Your approach seems well thought out, and the combination of visual and digital reminders could work effectively. Consider adding a brief check-in with a trusted colleague or friend to further reinforce your commitment and encourage accountability.

Thanks for the feedback, that makes sense. Adding a check-in with someone I trust could really help keep me grounded, especially on those tougher days.

Iâ€™m curious, though, how often do you think I should do these check-ins? Like, daily might be too much, but I donâ€™t wanna space them out so much that I lose momentum, ya know?

It's great that you're considering the frequency of check-ins! Since you mentioned daily might be too much, perhaps starting with 2-3 times a week could be a good balance, allowing you to maintain momentum while also giving you some flexibility to adjust as needed. How does that sound to you?

Hey, yeah, 2-3 times a week feels pretty doable, like itâ€™s enough to keep me in check without feeling like a chore. Do you think I should have a set schedule for those, or just kinda play it by ear based on how Iâ€™m feeling each week?

Thatâ€™s a good question to consider. Iâ€™m leaning towards playing it by ear since my weeks can get pretty unpredictable with school and research, but Iâ€™m worried I might slack off without a set planâ€”what do you think would work best for keeping me consistent?

I think having the flexibility to play it by ear makes sense given your unpredictable schedule, but maybe setting a loose goal, like aiming for mid-week and end-of-week check-ins, could help keep you on track. What do you think about starting with that and adjusting if you notice yourself slipping?
